Feature: Are there definite or specific articles?
Do indefinite nominals commonly have indefinite articles?
Are there prenominal articles?
Are there postnominal articles?
What is the order of numeral and noun in the NP?
What is the order of adnominal demonstrative and noun?
Can adnominal property words occur discontinuously?
Are nominal conjunction and comitative expressed by different elements?
Detailed comment:
conjunction: baa
comitative: possessive marker -tai, -n in the instrumental case

Feature: Is there an inclusive/exclusive distinction?
Comment: only in oblique stems, retained only formally, but not functionally
Example:
bidn-ii, bidn-ai, byadn-ai [1PL.INCL-GEN]
man-ai

Feature: Is there a gender distinction in independent 3rd person pronouns?
Is there a dual or unit augmented form (in addition to plural or augmented) for all person categories in the pronoun system?
Comment: it is described as EXCL/INCL distinction, but translated as ‘you and me’ for INCL

Feature: Are there three or more distance contrasts in demonstratives?
Example:
e- ‘this’
te- ‘that’

Feature: Do demonstratives show an elevation distinction?
Do demonstratives show a visible-nonvisible distinction?
Are there demonstrative classifiers?
Is there nonphonological allomorphy of noun number markers?
Are there several nouns (more than three) which are suppletive for number?
Is there productive overt morphological singular marking on nouns?
Is there productive morphological dual marking on nouns?
Is there productive morphological plural marking on nouns?
Comment: not obligatory, applies only to animate nouns
Example:
balg-ed
[city-PL]

Feature: Is there an associative plural marker for nouns?
Comment: Not mentioned, the collective suffix does not fulfil the conditions for ‘1’

Feature: Is there a productive morphological pattern for deriving an action/state noun from a verb?
Example: saa-ly [milk-NMLZ] ‘milking’

Feature: Is there a productive morphological pattern for deriving an agent noun from a verb?
Example: bic-eec [write-NMLZ] ‘scribe’

Feature: Is there a productive morphological pattern for deriving an object noun from a verb?
Example: bic ‘write’ - bic-eg [write-NMLZ] ‘letter’

Feature: Is there a noun class/gender system where sex is a factor in class assignment?
Is there a noun class/gender system where shape is a factor in class assignment?
Is there a noun class/gender system where animacy is a factor in class assignment?
Is there a noun class/gender system where plant status is a factor in class assignment?
Are there numeral classifiers?
Are there possessive classifiers?
Is the adnominal possessive construction different for alienable and inalienable nouns?
Comment: there is a tendency, but this is not the major pattern: alienable: possessive pronoun, inalienable: possessive suffix
Detailed comment: “There is a tendency in the modern dialects of Mongolian to use the possessive suffixes in their strictly possessive function only with reference to close and intimate (often, inalienable) relationships, as in connection with kinship terms […].”
Example:
duu-men [younger.brother-1SG] ‘my younger brother’
main-ai ger-t
[1PL.EXCL-GEN house-DAT]
‘in our house’

Feature: What is the pragmatically unmarked order of adnominal possessor noun and possessed noun?
Example:
min-ii eej
[1SG-GEN mother]
‘my mother’
duu-men
[younger.brother-1SG]
‘my younger brother’

Feature: Do core adjectives (defined semantically as property concepts such as value, shape, age, dimension) act like verbs in predicative position?
Example:
ter sain bai-jai
[that good be-RES]
‘That was fine.’

Feature: Do core adjectives (defined semantically as property concepts; value, shape, age, dimension) used attributively require the same morphological treatment as verbs?
Example:
ter yix sain nom
[that big good book]
‘That is a very good book.’

Feature: Are there morphological cases for non-pronominal core arguments (i.e. S/A/P)?
Example:
neg mory-ii.g ab-sen
[one horse-ACC buy-PTCP.PFV]
‘I bought a certain horse.’

Feature: Are there morphological cases for pronominal core arguments (i.e. S/A/P)?
Are there morphological cases for oblique non-pronominal NPs (i.e. not S/A/P)?
Are there morphological cases for oblique independent personal pronouns (i.e. not S/A/P)?
Are there prepositions?
Are there postpositions?
Do verbs have prefixes/proclitics, other than those that ONLY mark A, S or O (do include portmanteau: A & S + TAM)?
Do verbs have suffixes/enclitics, other than those that ONLY mark A, S or O (do include portmanteau: A & S + TAM)?
Is there productive infixation in verbs?
Is there overt morphological marking of present tense on verbs?
Is there overt morphological marking on the verb dedicated to past tense?
Comment: one marker also has “terminative” meaning, another “resultative”

Feature: Is there overt morphological marking on the verb dedicated to future tense?
Is a morphological distinction between perfective and imperfective aspect available on verbs?
Can the S argument be indexed by a suffix/enclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?
Comment: “Since the Mongolian verb has no personal conjugation, there is no formal agreement between the subject and the predicate with regard to number or person. Exceptions from this are formed by the reciprocal, cooperative and pluritative voices, which inherently imply and require a plural subject. The reciprocal (mutual action) and the cooperative (joint action) have, however, clear (often lexicalized) semantic profiles of their own, while only the pluritative (plural action) may be seen as a candidate for a true plural form of the verb. Certainly, the pluritative cannot be combined with a singular subject, which means that its use may be seen as an agreement phenomenon. On the other hand, its use is not obligatory, for it can always be replaced by the corresponding unmarked form”

Feature: Can the S argument be indexed by a prefix/proclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?
Can the A argument be indexed by a suffix/enclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?
Can the A argument be indexed by a prefix/proclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?
Can the P argument be indexed by a suffix/enclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?
Can the P argument be indexed by a prefix/proclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?
Are variations in marking strategies of core participants based on TAM distinctions?
Are variations in marking strategies of core participants based on verb classes?
Are variations in marking strategies of core participants based on person distinctions?
Can verb stems alter according to the person of a core participant?
Is there a benefactive applicative marker on the verb (including indexing)?
Is there an instrumental applicative marker on the verb (including indexing)?
Can the recipient in a ditransitive construction be marked like the monotransitive patient?
Comment: recipient: DAT; DO: either unmarked, or ACC; “the direct and the indirect object have always different marking in Mongolian”

Feature: Can standard negation be marked by an affix, clitic or modification of the verb?
Is there directional or locative morphological marking on verbs?
Is there verb suppletion for participant number?
Is there verb suppletion for tense or aspect?
Are there conjugation classes?
Are there verbal affixes or clitics that turn intransitive verbs into transitive ones?

Example:
yader-tl-aan
[become.tired-TERM-REFL]
‘until (one) becomes tired’
uj-emc-een
[see-IMM-REFL]
’as soon as (it) saw’

Feature: Is there a phonologically bound reciprocal marker on the verb?
Example:
boulaa [seize] ‘to seize’
boulaa-ld [seize-RECIP] ‘to seize each other’

Feature: Do verbs classify the shape, size or consistency of absolutive arguments by means of incorporated nouns, verbal affixes or suppletive verb stems?
Is there a copula for predicate nominals?
Are there serial verb constructions?
Can mood be marked by an inflecting word ("auxiliary verb")?
Example: bol- ‘to be, to become’ > ‘to be possible / allowed’ (possibility of action), med- ‘to know, to  nd out’ > ‘to be possible’ (possibility of action), cad- ‘to be able to’ (capability of action), diil- ‘to win, to overcome’ > ‘to be able to’ (capability of action), yad- ‘to be unable to’ (lexical negation of capability of action), udz- ‘to see’ > ‘to try’ (attempt of action).

Feature: Can aspect be marked by an inflecting word ("auxiliary verb")?
Example: bai- ‘to be’ (copula-existential) > ‘to be engaged in doing some- thing’ (progressive action), soo- ‘to sit, to dwell, to live’ > ‘to do something continu- ously’ (continuity of action), yab- ‘to depart, to act’ > ‘to continue doing something’ (continuity of action), exl- ‘to begin’ (beginning of action), bar- ‘to  nish’ (end of action), guitz- ‘to come to an end’ (end of action), oryx- ‘to throw’ > ‘to do something completely’ (completion of action), xay- ‘to throw (away)’ > ‘to do something rapidly and completely’ (completion of action).

Feature: Can tense be marked by an inflecting word ("auxiliary verb")?
Is verb compounding a regular process?
Are there verb-adjunct (aka light-verb) constructions?
Is incorporation of nouns into verbs a productive intransitivizing process?
Comment: the elements in the construction do not constitute a phonological word
Example:
nouteg boutz-sen
[homeland return-PTCP.PFV]
‘He returned to his homeland.’

Feature: Is there an existential verb?
Comment: it is identical with the equative copula

Feature: Are different posture verbs used obligatorily depending on an inanimate locatum's shape or position (e.g. 'to lie' vs. 'to stand')?
Is there a notably small number, i.e. about 100 or less, of verb roots in the language?
What is the pragmatically unmarked order of S and V in intransitive clauses?
Is a pragmatically unmarked constituent order verb-initial for transitive clauses?
Is a pragmatically unmarked constituent order verb-medial for transitive clauses?
Is a pragmatically unmarked constituent order verb-final for transitive clauses?
Is the order of constituents the same in main and subordinate clauses?
Do clausal objects usually occur in the same position as nominal objects?
Example:
bii monggel xel jaaxen med-e.n’
[1SG Mongol language little know-DUR]
‘I know some Mongolian.’
taa xyated xel-ii.g sain med-deg
[2PL Chinese language-ACC good know-P.HAB]
‘You know Chinese well.’
mart-e.j cad-ex=gwai-g.ee med-e.j bai-n’
[forget-C.IMPRF be.able-P.FUT=PRIV-RX know-C.IMPRF be-DUR]
‘I know I cannot forget.’

Feature: Is the order of core argument (i.e. S/A/P) constituents fixed?
Can standard negation be marked clause-finally?
Comment: “the positioning of the negation particles es and ul, which, as far as they are still in use, are always placed before the verbal form they negate.”

Feature: Can standard negation be marked clause-initially?
Is there a difference between imperative (prohibitive) and declarative negation constructions?
Example:
PROH: buu, bitgii
declarative: es, ul

Feature: Is verbal predication marked by the same negator as all of the following types of predication: locational, existential and nominal?
Example:
existential: ugwai ‘(there is) not, none’
equative: bish
verbal: es, ul

Feature: Is there a morpho-syntactic distinction between predicates expressing controlled versus uncontrolled events or states?
Comment: The object is coded differently depending on whether the action performed upon it was intentional or unintentional.
Example:
bii naidz-d-aa aryx oo-legh-sen
[SG1P friend-DAT-REFL liquor drink-CAUS-PTCP.PFV]
‘I (unintentionally) let my friend drink liquor.’
bii naidz-aar-aa aryx oo-legh-sen
[1SG friend-INSTR-REFL liquor drink-CAUS-PTCP.PFV]
‘I (intentionally) let my friend drink liquor.’

Feature: Is there a morphological passive marked on the lexical verb?
Example:
moor noxai/n-d bary-e.gd-eb
[cat dog-DAT catch-PASS-TERM]
‘The cat was caught by the dog.’

Feature: Is there a morphological antipassive marked on the lexical verb?
Is there a morphologically marked inverse on verbs?
Is there clause chaining?
Comment: “The converbialization of verbals is an operation that allows verbals to be chained into strings of two or more interconnected predicates within a single complex sentence. In such a sentence, only the last verbal stands in a  nite form or in a participial form functioning as a  nite predicate, while the other verbals are in special forms known as “converbs” (or also, “gerunds”).”

Feature: Is there an overt verb marker dedicated to signalling coreference or noncoreference between the subject of one clause and an argument of an adjacent clause ("switch reference")?
Is there a morphologically marked distinction between simultaneous and sequential clauses?
Comment: the modal converb “indicates simultaneous action or the mode of action (‘by doing’), very much like the imperfective converb, with which it is occasionally interchangeable"

Feature: Are causatives formed by affixes or clitics on verbs?
Is there a causative construction involving an element that is unmistakably grammaticalized from a verb for 'to say'?
Are verbs reduplicated?
Are nouns reduplicated?
Are elements apart from verbs or nouns reduplicated?
Comment: they don’t constitute a single phonological unit

Is there productive morphological paucal marking on nouns?

Feature: Can an adnominal demonstrative agree with the noun in number?
Detailed comment: “The plural forms are e-d vs. te-d, in oblique stems normally e-d//n- vs. te-d//n-, and they can be expanded by the regular plural marker -ner (+human) as well as by the idiosyncratic element -geer (±human).”
Example:
e-d-geer xum-uus
[this-PL-? person-PL]
‘these people’

Feature: Can an article agree with the noun in number?

Example: -xen

 en’ neeree yuu g-e.j ner-tai tzetzeg=bwai

bi nom-tai bai-n’

finite verbal forms used in interrogative are identical with the ones used in declarative clauses, non-finite are different though. These suffixes appear before the interrogative particle =uu

Comment: in conditional subordinate clauses the subject is marked by GEN or ACC

Feature: Do core adjectives (defined semantically as property concepts such as value, shape, age, dimension) act like nouns in predicative position?

ter sain bai-jai
[that good be-RES]

ter yix sain nom
[that big good book]
‘That is a very good book.’

Feature: Is there a non-initial velar nasal?
Is there a reciprocal marker that is distinct from the reflexive marker?
Example:
reflexive marker on the verb: -a:n
reciprocal marker on the verb: -ld
reflexive pronoun: eor
reciprocal pronoun: biü biü-een

Feature: Are there deranked purpose clauses?
Can the notional subject of a want complement clause be left implicit when it is coreferential with the wanter?
Is there a voicing distinction in fricatives?
Are there two separate liquid phonemes (r/l)?
Is there vowel length distinction?
Example: bal [pa􏰛] ‘honey’ vs. baal- [pa􏰔􏰛] ‘to harrow’; il [i􏰛] ‘clear’ vs. iil- [i􏰔􏰛] ‘to flee’ vs. eel [e􏰔􏰛] ‘blessing’; bol- [p􏰡􏰛] ‘to become’ vs. bool [p􏰡􏰔􏰛] ‘slave’; öl [o􏰛] ‘grey’ vs. ööl- [o􏰔􏰛] ‘to trim’; ul [􏰙􏰛] ‘sole’ vs. uul [􏰙􏰔􏰛] ‘mountain’; ül- [u􏰛] ‘to remain’ vs. üül [u􏰔􏰛] ‘cloud’, il ‘clear’ - i:l ‘to flee’

Feature: Are causative posture verbs derived and static-dynamic verbs basic?
Is there a male/female distinction in the sibling terms from the perspective of the speaker?
Is there an age distinction in sibling terms?
Are nouns most commonly derived from verbs than the other way around?
Are ‘hand’ and ‘arm’ expressed by the same term?
Example:
ARM: gar "hand, Hände; Arm, Arme"
HAND: gar	"hand, Hände; Arm, Arme"

Feature: Are ‘moon’ and ‘month’ expressed by the same term?
Is there a plural/collective suffix that is restricted to animates?
Can scalar additive operators (‘even’) also be used in non-scalar contexts (also)?
Is there a reflexive-possessive affix?
Are demonstratives verbally encoded?
Detailed comment:
there are demonstrative verbs
e-ng-g- ~ i-ng-g- ‘to do like this’ (< *ei-n+ki-) vs. te-g- ‘to do like that’ (< *tei-n+ki-)

Feature: Do cardinal numerals require agreement on noun phrases?
Is nominative case unmarked?
Are accusative-marked objects specific while unmarked objects are non-specific?
Are recipient and location expressed by the same marker?
Is there a distinction between marking of interrogation in polar and content questions?
Detailed comment: “Mongolian makes a systematic formal distinction between polar (yes/no) and non-polar (wh-) questions, in that the former are marked by the interrogative particle =UU (a er vowels =y.UU), while the latter are marked by the corrogative particle =b (syllabi ed as =e.b).”

Feature: Is acting agent in passive clause expressed by a dative-marked noun phrase?
Example:
moor noxai/n-d bary-e.gd-eb
[cat dog-DAT catch-PASS-TERM]
‘The cat was caught by the dog.’

Feature: Is the subject of an adnominalized clause marked by the genitive case?
Can a passive construction have adversative meaning?
Can demonstrative/interrogative verbs be derived from pronouns and light verbs ‘to do’?
Are causative and passive expressed by a formally identical marker?
Are converb suffixes and deverbal noun suffixes formally identical?
Are quotative markers adverbial derivations from a verb ‘to say’?
Can relational adpositions (e.g. ‘under’) be derived from a place noun (e.g. ‘bottom’) and a locational suffix (e.g. at LOC)?
Example:
ger dot-er
[house inside-LOC]
‘inside the house’
ter ger-ii.n dot-er
[that house-GEN inside-LOC]
‘inside that house’
ter shireen-ii dee-r
